creator: ferguson_1950

content:
ferguson_1950 said
May I ask whether Thunderbird has recently been upgraded " I now cannot send or receive emails and am wondering whether it is Thunderbird or Telstra at fault

Thunderbird gets an update about every four weeks. To check exact release dates check here https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/releases/

My guess is it will be neither Telstra or Thunderbird but your antivirus product. Norton are the flavour of the week blocking folk at the moment, but it changes frequently as to which product are topping the charts here. Norton is mentioned in dispatches very frequently however.

But you might want to actually post your error message so I can do more than guess.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You have a problem with your antivirus is my guess and do not, and probably did not have, any problems in Thunderbird that you could fix but uninstalling it.

Most of those posting this week with these sorts of issues are Norton customers. Are you? You might want to apply the fix for your issue they have if you are.

Also it claims there is a potential security threat with Thunderbird's own web addresses: "live.thunderbird.net." and "addons.thunderbird.net.".

This error is a strong indicator your antivirus product is the root cause and has changed the self signed certificates they use. Thunderbird does not automatically trust self signed certificates. It must be told they are Ok, by the user who can make an informed decision that they trust the issuer shown in the certificate

content:
Oauth operates on the issue of token that are updated after you initially authorize access for as long or as little time as the server operator decides. It has nothing to do with Thunderbird.

I have found with my Google accounts that;

  • Changing my ISP triggered a reauthorization.
  • Changing my device (new computer) triggered a reauthentication.
  • And through anecdotal sources using a VPN can also be a trigger.

All things that Google might consider a "change" to your access which might indicate a hacking attempt. I do not know what your individual circumstances are, but you will have to reauthenticate as often as your provider requires it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
First, uninstalling and reinstalling is NEVER a solution unless Thunderbird itself is not functioning or menus aren't working or screens are frozen repeatedly. Second, thunderbird is designed such that reinstalling need not affect the accounts. That is, before doing anything major, you should always 1) exit thunderbird and then, 2) copy the profile elsewhere. Also, the final prompt on an uninstall is whether to delete account data. So, even if you did a reinstall, the accounts will still be there and not lost. But it's not needed. I just added that as extra info.

On your problem, it is often helpful to delete the account if it's cause setup problems. The DONE you mention just means that Thunderbird found the servers. Your individual account remains unconfirmed. I always propose omitting password during setup and waiting for the prompt for it. Posting screenshots of your incoming and outgoing settings often prove useful, so those with Yahoo experience can comment on the settings.
creator: davidsk

content:
Sometime the folder pane cache looses the plot. Try force rebuilding it by deleting the file.

In Thunderbird's help menu select troubleshooting information. Click the open profile folder button. Close down Thunderbird completely.

In the file manager instance that open with the profile folder in it, locate the file foldertree.json and delete it. Restart Thunderbird.

content:
For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

content:
I don't know what you mean by setting up for online storage, so I will assume you meant the folders were set for offline access an to sync 100% of the messages. Here are some possibilities: - click the synchronization pane - click 'advanced' button and untick all folders - change sync settings from 100% to a smaller number - also tick the box for messages above a certain size (make it small)

Since this is an IMAP account, you could also - exit thunderbird - locate the files (e.g. inbox, inbox.msf) in profile and delete them (or, if you are unsure, MOVE to another location) - tip: while there, look for any NSTMP files as they can be deleted. Look also for duplicate account setups (account names followed by -1, -2, etc.) as the NSTMP files can be immediately deleted, and the others have a possibility of having duplicates of your messages. If found you would need to review. - restart thunderbird and the folders will be repopulated.

Now, you can see whatever the savings are. This is a difficult assignment, because you still need headers of all messages so you can access as desired.
creator: davidsk

content: Ok, it's easier than it sounds, because the filter panes explain as you go. - click tools>message filters - at top, select the account and click the NEW button - at top, enter a name for it, whatever will remind you of its role - untick 'manually run' - click to run AFTER junk classification - set 'match any of the following' - set FROM and 'contains' and then enter enough of email address to be unique. doesn't have to be all - for actions, 1) set 'move to' and select your account's inbox and 2) set Junk to be 'not junk ' - click OK. you're done.

content:
david said
There is no whitelist feature in Thunderbird.

Actually there is David. The entire address book by default, although individual address books can be selected and deselected in account settings > Junk Settings. I have already told the OP this in another topic he posted in. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1439443#answer-1656292


Derek Williams said
Email from a trusted address over past decade is suddenly going to Junk as of today. Cannot see how to whitelist the Sender, and googling the question tells me to go to Tools>Options, however Options does not show in the Tools menu.

  • This image shows spam items with the message subject edited to include the text ** SPAM **.
  • It is also clear that the flame icon between the name and date columns is not the red it is set to when Thunderbird marks a message as Junk/SPAM.

These two things are an obvious and definitive proof that Thunderbird did not detect this email as spam. You are looking for an outside source to Thunderbird. Thunderbird does not make any modification to the email subject and does set the junk/spam flag so the icon will be red.

A google search of ** SPAM ** indicates that Avast adds this when it's spam engine thinks it has found spam. https://forum.avast.com/index.php?topic=177712.0

As Gen digital own all of the following brands Norton, Avast, LifeLock, Avira, AVG, ReputationDefender and CCleaner it would be reasonable to expect all of them to do something similar if they have a spam/scam detection module so as I told you before, look to your antivirus product.

Then look at your mail providers website for spam filtering options. This thread indicates that spamassasin a server side product also adds the subject entry ** SPAM **. https://support.google.com/mail/thread/14798766/emails-being-sent-to-people-with-spam-headers?hl=en

What exactly is the cause of your issue today is not clear. What is clear is Thunderbird is not the issue on this occasion, only the messenger.

content:
You might want to check in Windows that Thunderbird has in fact terminated. Just because there is not visible window does not mean the program is shut down. It may still be in process for a very long time if your antivirus is causing issues. Like hung by the antivirus not releasing foes to be updated slow

Press alt+Ctrl +delete on your keyboard and select task manager from the menu.

Search the list to ensure Thunderbird is not present, either as an app or a background process. The background process is what it becomes when the last window is closed, until is actually shuts down.

content: A simple way to offload your accounts from c to d is to do this: - exit thunderbird if running - copy the profile from wherever it is on drive c to drive d. Name it something simple to remember - open the profiles.ini file at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird and change it to point to drive D. This needs to be the explicit location for Thunderbird to use to access the profile (DO an BACKUP of profiles.ini FIRST) - start thunderbird and make sure all is well. You can confirm all is well by clicking account settings and then server settings and note that the bottom line of pane is pointing to drive d. - you can now delete the profile folder itself on drive c. that leaves only the appdata\thunderbird folder You now have all thunderbird data on D. - for backups, just exit thunderbird and copy the D profile to external media. I also encourage copying the appdata\thunderbird folder to make it easier for any future reinstall.

content:
Hi David: I want to thank you for your reply, your suggestion did not resolve my problem directly, but it did help me solve my problem indirectly! ;-)

I had forgotten that an icon/app ("icon" is the old timers name, "which I am", and "app" is the new way of addressing them), could still open, but yet be corrupt, and cause you nothing but grief, like it was causing me every time I opened the program! That is what happened to my Thunderbird icon/app, why did it happen? I have no idea, but it is now fixed! :-)

I went into "File Explorer" to locate the "prefs.js file", as you suggested, but I was unable to find it there, I even looked under: Users/myname/AppData/Local/Mozilla/Profiles it was no where to be found, then it dawned on me that my icon/app could be corrupt! So I saw the "icon/app" in the folder called "Programs/Mozilla Thunderbird" and I clicked on it and it opened right up, without asking me for that password....YEA!!!!! Problem solved, maybe.......?

I thought no way could it be that simple, so I rebooted my computer, actually expecting it to ask me for the password again, but was pleasantly surprised, that the password box did not reappear!!! :-)

I deleted the corrupt icon/app and replaced it with a new one and its working flawlessly, just like before, THANK YOU for indirectly resolving my problem David. Sincerely Keith aka NiceSeeingYou

content:
Remove your signature and try to send.

Email signatures are a common cause of false positives in outgoing spam detection tools used by providers that rarely actually understand email at all. Hence their reliance on the web portal someone else maintains for them.

At a specific level it is often the images used for social media (Facebook, X etc) that have been used in spam and are now in your signature than are the cause, but the general remove your signature is a good starting point.

Another specific is using a signature generated in Microsoft Word. It sounds innocuous, but the paste from Word brings hundred of thousands of useless characters with it that includes items that can actually be used in spam. Essentially the same template data is send from word every time, even if it is hidden from view it is in the email and can form part of the spam signature used by the detection software.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Press F10 to make the menu bar visible if it is not already. Select View menu > headers and set it to normal. It will probably be set to all.

content: That appearance and file name would indicate you have had, or continue to have, duplicate emails being downloaded from the pop account. Is that the case?
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I have had several duplicate emails but did not consider it a big problem. The "popstate-1.dat" folder does not have an emails in it.
creator: mcintoshbear

content: @Matt can explain the cause of this problem, but the appearance of a '-1' version indicates you have had connectivity problems. The popstate.dat file just keeps track of the most recently downloaded message. If the file becomes corrupted, Thunderbird will reset the count by downloading all messages again.
creator: davidsk

content:
The most common cause is antivirus programs, but anything that causes file contention can result in these duplicate files being written. Any occurrence of a file or folder with a -Number is a sign of contention

Certainly try deleting it from the Thunderbird folders, but if it does not work we will have to go though removing it from the underlying file system. Post back and I will write some instructions.

I strongly suggest you create an exception in you antivirus program for your Thunderbird profile folders as having contention issues is a serious bane to reliability.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I created the following exception in my antivirus software

C:\Users\My PC\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles

I did not include sub-folders.

I deleted the "popstate-1.dat" folder and then restarted Thunderbird. The deleted folder was not in either Trash folder. The deleted folder was not recreated in Thunderbird after restarting.

I will monitor for several days before I close this support thread.
creator: mcintoshbear

content:
For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX
creator: MattAuSupport
